name: nytimes
text:
For the first time since 2011, NASA astronauts are scheduled to launch from U.S. soil to the International Space Station.

It will mark the first time that a private American company, Elon Musk’s SpaceX, is in charge of sending astronauts into orbit. https://t.co/bWPDdEzqoJ

name: nytimes
text:
The crew of the spacecraft, Douglas Hurley and Robert Behnken, are both NASA astronauts, but the control room will be run by SpaceX employees
https://t.co/ViHFEMyqSU https://t.co/b8h9MKJs33

name: nytimes
text:
Astronauts Hurley and Behnken will be the first to test the Crew Dragon capsule in orbit.
https://t.co/qQ7K3RKkmC https://t.co/ZajE7tM35R

name: nytimes
text:
Crew Dragon has more room and can carry more people than the Apollo capsules that flew astronauts to the moon. Future flights could carry 4 astronauts to the station.
https://t.co/5zekg4UQdT https://t.co/To0zKKbvzQ

name: nytimes
text:
The new capsule includes a touchscreen interface for the astronauts, replacing the knobs, buttons and switches used to control the space shuttle and Apollo spacecraft.
https://t.co/CSaa9gqMBO https://t.co/6mVWo8TqAd

name: nytimes
text: The Crew Dragon passed a major in-flight safety test earlier this year, when an unoccupied capsule separated from its rocket moments after liftoff and parachuted into the Atlantic Ocean. https://t.co/m5VgJfRIya https://t.co/1hZICdeYPn

name: nytimes
text: If a private company can loft humans into orbit today, why not the moon next, or Mars in the future? A successful launch could ignite a future long imagined by science fiction writers in which space is a destination for more and more people. https://t.co/JCaLhFqtFp

text:
